A government has two basic responsibilities.

To defend the borders and deliver the mail.

FedEx and UPS are already contracted to hand off money-losing deliveries to the Postal Service.

Where, in your scheme, do you see either of them bidding into a money-losing proposoition? A staffed fleet capable of going to every door in the country, whether they have mail today or not?

Economics 101 for elucidation. Universal postal service has, in recent years, become a market failure. Essential services that fail the market test are called government functions.

Online advertising revenues are down across the board despite increases in spending, just because of the competition. I mean, really, what do you need to set up a web advertising company? Cooperation with a content provider seems to be it, and there are entirely too many willing content providers running specialty forums where advertising is easily targeted and the providers willing to take a minimal fee for impressions, as often they run their boards for free without ads anyway. Reaching out to those who run the boards is easy and worth it for small competitors who can then underbid Microsoft and other big companies for ad impressions.

It's totally cutthroat when all it takes to compete is bandwidth and some relatively inexpensive servers.

if things go on like this, time is not far away when Gurgaon will be slide into oblivion like Tuglaqabad did in the medeival times. Is history repeating itself?
Why don't you petition the U.S. government to send billions of U.S. dollars in free grant money to India to fund the development of nuclear and alternative energy power plants?

Burning coal to power air-conditioners is madness. Every degree cooled today will ramp up temperatures tomorrow, unless the power source is NOT a fossil fuel. The fires we are seeing in the American West, the droughts and heat waves will consume us all if we don't change our ways.

We hear these excuses from power company officials every year. However, the problem persists because the real issues are not addressed.

The line losses and theft come to 33%. Bad debts can go upto 10%.

The electricity distribution company is severely understaffed, with the sanctioned strength not being revised for over a decade though Gurgaon has more than tripled in population. 30000 vacancies exist even in the present staffing. Authorities inform us that these are being filled now.

The power distribution company consumers complain of non-responsive staff who do not bother about repairing faults promptly and are often rude. Customer care centers are in a pathetic state.

Transformers in many colonies are under -capacity and often fail, especially when there is a power surge after resumption of power.

This is the situation when nearly a third of Gurgaon is yet to be occupied. Now the government has doubled the number of sectors. The power demand in three years can well be more than two and a half times it is at present. The same excuses about demand exceeding supply will be trotted out again.

The situation will not improve unless the distribution company is better managed by top administrators who are held accountable for performance and do not get transferred every one or two years as has been happening at present. The company also needs to be recapitalized.

Member,
Power Subcommittee
Joint Action Forum of Residents' Welfare Associations (JAFRA GURGAON)
Correction in my previous comment. The number of vacancies is about 3000 and not 30000 as erroneously mentioned.

I am an entrepreneur and run an Inbound Marketing Consulting firm in Gurgaon. I have been in the city for the last four years. All the years and the months have been similar with respect to the power situation . This summer, it just got worse. While power generation and distribution are definitely problems and would not really resolve for a long long time (owing to structural issues), the real casualty has been the basic quality of life. Added to it the additional direct costs of power backup and the indirect cost of failing electrical appliances owing to erratic power. And yes, if the appliances in our home and office could cry, they would have perished by now. Sadly, urban centres like Gurgaon have lost the plot, in terms of basic civic amenities.

Note to Writer
It would be wonderful if you could do a follow up post that details out the exact issues being faced by Gurgaon in terms of power. The post can start from Generation and track transmission and distribution. I am sure you will have enough stories to last a year.

Thanks for your comment because you prove the point made by this article. Even a government appointed Banerjee commission came to the conclusion that the fire in the coach was accidental. Now that might or might not be true. Even if we accept your claim that the train was set on fire by a mob then it was the responsibility of the state to bring the perpetrators of the crime to justice. This is what civilized societies do. What happened in Gujarat was state sponsored genocide of minorities. It is a shame for India that a person like Mr. Modi holds high office. It would be like the leader of the Ku  Klux Klan becoming a governor of some state in the USA. And you also go on to assert that state sponsored genocide acted as a deterrence against further violence. You are wrong. Very serious acts violence were committed inside the Akshardham temple and the same repeated in attacks on Ahmedabad in 2008. Even the 26/11 attackers justified their actions by citing Gujarat much like you commend state sponsored terrorism by citing Godhra as the reason. Terrorism in all its form has to be fought and condemned.
